meta.purpose: Track competing theses about Berkshire's 2026 positioning. Evidence accumulates organically each week. No rigid scoring—just pattern recognition for when signals emerge.
meta.evaluation_approach: Re-read this file each week, add new evidence under appropriate thesis, note any inflection points

bear_case.label: Tech Underexposure Thesis
bear_case.author: Steven Fiorillo (Seeking Alpha)
bear_case.core_argument: Berkshire will continue underperforming because 2026 will be 'risk-on, tech-led' and Berkshire is defensively positioned with massive cash and tech underexposure.
key_predictions: 2026 market will be tech-led, similar to 2020-2025
Declining Treasury yields will erode BRK's $11B annual T-bill income
BRK.B will continue underperforming S&P 500 by 5-10pp
Cash position is a structural drag, not strategic optionality
Greg Abel will need to shift toward tech to reverse underperformance
what_would_prove_this_right: T-bill yields decline significantly, reducing investment income
Abel announces tech-focused acquisitions or portfolio shifts

evidence_log.data: BRK.B underperformance gap widened from -5.80pp (W51) to -8.15pp (W52), accelerating divergence
Tech holdings stabilized (AAPL -0.16%, GOOGL -0.34%) but couldn't drive portfolio performance
Most holdings declined broadly, suggesting market favoring different sectors than BRK exposure

bull_case.label: Sector Rotation Thesis (XLI/XLU Play)
bull_case.author: Luca Socci (Seeking Alpha)
bull_case.core_argument: Berkshire is perfectly positioned for 2026 sector rotation into Industrials (XLI) and Utilities (XLU). Focus on operating businesses (BNSF, BHE, Manufacturing), not equity portfolio.
key_predictions: 2026 will see 'revenge of the S&P 493' - equal-weight (RSP) outperforms cap-weight (SPY)
XLI and XLU will outperform market; XLE and XLY will lag
Industrial activity stabilization (not boom) is sufficient for XLI earnings growth
BHE's regulated returns and reinvestment will compound in higher-rate environment
BRK.B will outperform as sector rotation validates operating business positioning
what_would_prove_this_right: XLI and XLU outperform SPY by 5%+ in 2026
BNSF continues showing pricing power despite mixed volumes
BHE reports expanding margins and accelerating capex deployment
Manufacturing segment shows volume acceleration and margin expansion
BRK.B underperformance gap narrows, then reverses to outperformance

evidence_log.data: Q3 2025: BNSF after-tax earnings +10.0% YTD despite mixed volumes, demonstrating pricing power
Q3 2025: BHE electric utility margin +9.9% YTD with retail volumes +2.7% (MidAmerican +9.8%)
Q3 2025: Manufacturing industrial products pre-tax earnings +24.3% with volume acceleration (Q3 -1.9% vs YTD -3.8%)
Moody's (MCO) was only major gainer in W52 (+3.20%), suggesting credit/industrial activity strengthening
BRK.B stock underperformance accelerated in W52, market not yet pricing in sector rotation thesis

2025-W52.market_context: Holiday week, low volume, CEO transition T-minus 9 days

sector_performance.note: Limited data for holiday week; Moody's (MCO) +3.20% only standout

operating_business_signals.bnsf: Q3 data shows +10% YTD earnings growth with pricing power
operating_business_signals.bhe: Q3 data shows +9.9% YTD margin expansion
operating_business_signals.manufacturing: Q3 data shows industrial products accelerating with +24.3% earnings growth

2025-W52.which_thesis_winning: Too early to call. Stock performance supports bear case, but operating fundamentals support bull case. Market may be mispricing BRK based on equity portfolio rather than operating businesses.
2025-W52.key_question: Is BRK.B underperformance a lagging indicator (market hasn't recognized operating strength yet) or a leading indicator (operating strength won't translate to stock performance)?

signals: Any strategic announcements about capital deployment
Changes to portfolio allocation (tech adds vs industrial adds)
Did Apple trimming continue? (bear case if yes)
Any new tech positions added? (bear case if yes)
Any new industrial/utility positions? (bull case if yes)
RSP vs SPY performance (equal-weight vs cap-weight)
Volume trends (stabilizing = bull case, declining = bear case)
Pricing power continuing (margins expanding = bull case)
Industrial products freight volumes (acceleration = bull case)

notes_for_next_week: Week 2025-W53 (Dec 29 - Jan 4) will include Jan 1 CEO transition. Watch for any announcements.
Re-read both Fiorillo and Socci articles before W53 analysis to keep frameworks fresh.
When adding evidence, tag as 'supporting' or 'challenging' for each thesis.
Don't force a conclusion—let the evidence accumulate. Inflection points will become obvious.
Key principle: We're not trying to predict which thesis wins. We're trying to recognize when the market signals which thesis IS winning.
